citation.article-title: Psychroserpens burtonensis gen. nov., sp. nov., and Gelidibacter algens gen. nov., sp. nov., psychrophilic bacteria isolated from antarctic lacustrine and sea ice habitats

p.s: Description of Gelidibacter algens sp. nov.
Gelidibacter algens (al'gens. L. part. adj. algens, feeling cold, referring to the sea ice habitat)
The characteristics of Gelidibacter algens are the same as those of the genus.
In addition, growth occurs in 0.4X to 1.5X seawater.
Psychrophilic, with growth occurring at 0°C and optimal growth occurring at 15 to 18°C.
No growth occurs at temperatures of 25°C or higher.
Starch, dextran, esculin, DNA, various Tweens, and L-tyrosine (no diffusible pigment is formed on tyrosine agar) are degraded.
Acid is produced from a limited number of carbohydrates, including L-arabinose, D-glucose, D-mannose, dextran, and starch.
Strains may degrade casein and/or gelatin.
Chitin, agar, urate, and xanthine are not degraded.
Negative for oxidase activity, urease activity, β-galactosidase activity (O-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside test), nitrate reduction, and hydrogen sulfide production (from thiosulfate).
Able to utilize a variety of organic acids and some carbohydrates, including D-glucose, as sole sources of carbon and energy (see Table 2 for additional phenotypic information).
The DNA G+C content is 36 to 38 mol% (as determined by the thermal denaturation procedure).
Colonies have spreading edges and a mucoid and sticky consistency, are 2 to 3 mm in diameter after 7 to 10 days of incubation, and are yellow pigmented.
The type strain is ACAM 536, which was isolated from a sea ice core collected from Ellis Fjord, Vestfold Hills, Antarctica.
